requiredPriorStandards.description: Partition circles and rectangles into two, three, or four equal shares, describe the shares using the words halves, thirds, half of, a third of, etc., and describe the whole as two halves, three thirds, four fourths. Recognize that equal shares of identical wholes need not have the same shape.
Measure the length of an object twice, using length units of different lengths for the two measurements; describe how the two measurements relate to the size of the unit chosen.

prerequisites.description: Can count objects and recognize quantities from 1 to 10
prerequisites.wonderHookQuestion: Luna has 3 friends coming to her party! Can you hold up 3 fingers?
alternativeAssessments: Can you draw 3 cookies on your canvas?
How many friends do you see in this picture? Let's count together!
gapSignals: holds up wrong number of fingers

microLesson.script: Let's count together! Watch my fingers: One finger... [pause] Two fingers... [pause] Three fingers! Now you try - show me 3 fingers!
microLesson.reAssessQuestion: Great! Now can you show me 4 fingers?

prerequisites.description: Can distinguish between objects that are the same size vs. different sizes
prerequisites.wonderHookQuestion: Look at these cookie pieces Luna cut! Are they the SAME size or DIFFERENT sizes?
alternativeAssessments: If YOU got this tiny piece and your friend got this BIG piece, would that be fair?
Which piece is bigger - this one or that one?
passSignals: this one is huge and that one is tiny
gapSignals: they look the same to me

microLesson.script: Let me show you! Look at THIS piece - it's BIG like this [gesture]. Now THIS piece - it's tiny like this [gesture]. See how one is HUGE and one is small? They're DIFFERENT sizes! When things are different sizes, we say they're NOT the same.
microLesson.reAssessQuestion: Now look again at these pieces - are they the same size or different sizes?

prerequisites.description: Understands that fair sharing means everyone gets the same amount
prerequisites.wonderHookQuestion: Luna cut the cookie but Carlos got a tiny piece and Maya got a HUGE piece. How do you think Carlos feels?
alternativeAssessments: If you had to share with your best friend, what would 'fair' mean?
Look at these pieces - is this fair for everyone? Why or why not?

microLesson.script: Think about your favorite treat - maybe cookies or pizza. If your friend got a HUGE piece and you got a teeny tiny piece, would you feel good? Probably not! Fair means everyone gets the SAME AMOUNT. That way, nobody feels sad.
microLesson.reAssessQuestion: So if we want to be fair, should everyone's piece be the same size or different sizes?

prerequisites.description: Can identify and name circles, rectangles, and squares
prerequisites.wonderHookQuestion: Can you draw a circle on your canvas? That'll be Luna's cookie!
alternativeAssessments: What shape is a pizza? Can you draw one?
Point to the circle in this picture!
gapSignals: draws square or rectangle when asked for circle
says 'I don't know what a circle is'

microLesson.script: A circle is a round shape - like a wheel, or a pizza, or the sun! Watch me trace one with my finger: round and round, no corners. Now you try! Make a round shape on your canvas.
microLesson.reAssessQuestion: Awesome! Now can you draw a square? That's a shape with 4 corners.

prerequisites.description: Understands 'half' means splitting something into 2 equal parts
prerequisites.wonderHookQuestion: If Luna cuts her cookie right down the middle into 2 equal pieces, what do we call each piece?
alternativeAssessments: If you split your sandwich with a friend, how many pieces is that?
passSignals: cut it in two equal parts

microLesson.script: When you cut something EXACTLY down the middle into 2 equal parts, each part is called a HALF. Like if you split a cookie right down the middle - you get 2 halves! Each person gets half of the cookie. Half means 'one of two equal parts.'
microLesson.reAssessQuestion: So if I split this into 2 equal parts, how many halves do I have?

prerequisites.description: Can compare quantities and identify which is more or less
prerequisites.wonderHookQuestion: Look at these two pieces - which one has MORE cookie? Point to it!
alternativeAssessments: If you wanted the biggest piece, which one would you pick?
Which friend got more - Carlos with the tiny piece or Maya with the big piece?

microLesson.script: MORE means bigger or greater amount. Look at these two pieces side by side. THIS one [point to big] takes up lots of space - that's MORE. THIS one [point to small] is tiny - that's LESS. Which one would give you more cookie to eat?
microLesson.reAssessQuestion: Point to the piece that has LESS cookie.

prerequisites.description: Understands that wholes can be divided into parts
prerequisites.wonderHookQuestion: If Luna wants to share her cookie with 3 friends, what does she need to do?
alternativeAssessments: Show me on the canvas how you'd cut this cookie for 3 people.
What happens when we need to share one thing with many friends?
gapSignals: give the whole thing to one person

microLesson.script: When we have ONE whole thing (like a cookie) and we need to share with MANY friends, we need to CUT it or DIVIDE it into pieces. That's called partitioning - making a whole into parts. Luna needs to cut her cookie into 3 pieces so each friend gets one!
microLesson.reAssessQuestion: If there were 4 friends, how many pieces would Luna need to cut?

assessmentFlow.description: Prerequisites are assessed invisibly through wonder hooks and natural conversation. Start with foundational (counting, equal/different) and progress to intermediate (half, partitioning) only if needed.

phases.description: First story engagement assesses comparison and fairness concepts through Luna's unequal cookie scenario
Canvas drawing requests assess counting and shape recognition naturally
Conversational probing before formal partitioning tasks checks part-whole understanding

metadata.author: Simili Pedagogy Team
metadata.notes: Invisible assessment strategies aligned with pedagogy design principles - assessment feels like wonder, not testing
